ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: So many insights about decision making and how to approach any strategic situation logically.
Introduction to game theory concepts
Introductory game theory: Nash equilibrium, payoff matrices, subgame perfect equilibrium, backwards induction, auctions, etc.
To evaluate problems with complete ration instead of intuition though it is not always practical
I learned how to translate certain situations into game theory games and how to solve these games.
The ability to think strategically about choosing an action in a game.

We discussed normal and extensive form games, Nash equilibrium, pure and mixed strategies, perfect/imperfect information games along with information sets, and the processes for solving these situations.

I have learnt about strategies in handling various everyday and business scenarios. Though the actual situations are far more complicated than the basic models taught in class, I gained much enlightenment form these models.
Theories and exemples in game theory. A mindset to solve problems by considering the consequences of one's own actions and others' possible actions.
that of game theory and thinking about the world in terms of cost and benefit

I believe that this course on game theory, provided me with a proper introduction to the field of behavioural sciences. I feel that this knowledge will help me significantly in the future as I plan on doing my masters in economics.
the basic knowledge of game theory
Learning to see real world situation as a game theorist prospective, now am acting effectively.
Strategic thinking

This course helped me learn more about the field of game theory and its real-life applications. I developed skills in strategic decision-making and analyzing games in a more formal and rational way. We learned about topics such as Nash Equilibrium, subgame-perfect equilibria, backwards induction, (weakly) dominant and dominated strategies and their successive elimination, extensive form games, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Many of the concepts covered in the long, strenuous lectures were never seen again. I would prefer it if the meat of the course was stuck to, tested on, and large key concepts that are applicable to everyday life were hammered in well.
Great material, however the course is very poorly organized and the instructor needs significant improvement in explaining and instructing in class.

Am I just stupid? This is the question that crossed my mind a lot when in this class. I have some background in ECON and I had to take this class as a graduation requirement. I thought hmm probably more efficient to take in the summer. I was very wrong. The professor was very kind and all the TAs were thoughtful HOWEVER the material was harder than it should have been. The professor didnt change his notes and material from his graduate course material on game theory. Thus this made the course unnecessarily complex in the explanation. You may be thinking, isnt this just you? While I may not be an Econ major, I have an incredibly strong background in maths and statistics. This class was much more complex than it should have been.

Strengths: Super generous grading on problem sets (complete/incomplete), practice exams were pretty good preparation for exams, notes were quite useful.
Improvements: Lectures could be more engagingsplitting up two big lectures into three smaller lectures would be great. Also, problem sets are not exactly representative of exams (but are generously graded).
IT's good. The final is somehow difficult than the sample
The lectures were very interesting and engaging. I wish that we had more exercises to practice on and not just theoretical questions in the PSETs.

Strengths: interesting material
Weaknesses: the professor's English is not very good, so sometimes it's hard to follow what he is trying to say

The pacing of the lectures were generally pretty slow, so I didn't attend them. The notes were somewhat poorly written at times so I ended up needing to search and learn many of the topics on my own. The homeworks were only checked for completion, which meant that we received no feedback other than the midterm and final, each of which represented a substantial portion of our grade. The scenarios and problems were generally pretty interesting, so that part was a positive.

The course gives us an overview of game theory and introduces several vital models and theorems in eight lessons. However, I think more classical models and more information about Bayesian Games can be covered if the course is extended to 10 lessons or more.

I feel playing videos is not so suitable for an online course, since the soundtrack is often not in sync with the picture. (I believe this was not caused by network problems because the other part of the class was just fine and the same problem occurs in other online classes.)
it's too lecture-y, but i think that has to do with the online format and the fact that it's 3 hours makes it very difficult to absorb things by the end.

As there was alot of material to go over, we didn't get the opportunity to interact with our peers or professor. Maybe next time, the number of hours alloted for this session can be increased to accommodate such considerations. Also, the homework questions we received, in my opinion were very difficult, and not being able to answer them left me demotivated and agitated at times. Even the final examination was considerably more difficult than the sample exam paper we were provided as reference.
Having said that, however, the professor's classes were very interesting and the notes he provided were especially useful.

strengths:the teacher's illastration is clear.
weaknesses:the questions for practice are lack and too hard
The exercise questions were hard for me. Even though, they were sometimes  solved by the TAs, I hoped we could have more explanation text solution.
Strength: good lecture notes; interesting psets. Weaknesses: too rushed and many topics were not covered in enough depth.
I think the course was well structured and went at a very good pace. Remote learning was very well supported and there was plenty of room/time for questions office hours etc.

I think the course was a good introduction to the field of game theory, but it attempted to cover to much in too short a period of time. Instead of focusing on the basics for us to apply to more complex games, sometimes I felt as though we tried to extend what we learned in class too quickly to scenarios beyond the scope of what we were learning. Furthermore, while what we learned in class was very much grounded in concrete examples, our tests were much more theoretical, and I feel like we were unprepared and could have benefitted from more explanation in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if are interested in and have a background in calculus and want to know how to apply it to real world strategic scenarios.
No. While the PSets are not graded on correctness, the questions are demoralizing. He takes questions from his graduate level game theory course. Its miserable.
Absolutely if you need the requirement. I would recommend taking it under Polak under normal session if you can, however. Otherwise, good for scheduling.
I would not. I did not leave the class feeling I know much more than I did before
Yes, there are lot of examples so that we can relate to real life
Yes, the professor is really good - uses examples from movies, which bring the concepts to life!
Yes I would. I do think that the skills I learned in this class were very valuable and can be applied in many situations.
Yes if he/she is an ECON major. It's not an easy course.
Yes.

Yes. The course is rather interesting and rewarding. For those majoring in Economics, the course absolutely helps with their lessons; for those from other departments, it is rather interesting to learn about the various models in class.
no, the in person one is much more engaging

I most definitely will. However, on converting the course fee from USD to INR, the resulting amount may be considered a bit much here in India. It would greatly benefit a major chunk of people if scholarship or some sort of assistance was available for summer school as well.
Yes.
Yes, I would recommend. The professor was kind, there were many exercise to think about, and the TA's were good.
To Economics and non Economics majors I think it's a very interesting course and one that definitely teaches many problem solving skills.

I would recommend this course to students that want to learn more about strategic thinking and how to analyze games. However, they should be prepared to put in a lot of effort outside of class to learn or relearn material on their own.
